('''AA''') is a [[major airlines of the United States|major American airline]] headquartered in [[Fort Worth, Texas]], within the [[Dallas–Fort Worth metroplex]]. It is the [[World's largest airlines|world's largest airline]] when measured by fleet size, revenue, scheduled passengers carried, scheduled passenger-kilometers flown, and number of destinations served. American, together with its regional partners, operates an extensive international and domestic network with almost 6,800 flights per day to nearly 350 destinations in more than 50 countries.{{cite web|url=https://www.aa.com/i18n/customer-service/about-us/american-airlines-group.jsp|title=American Airlines Group − About us − American Airlines|last=|first=|date=|website=Aa.com|accessdate=February 22, 2018}} American Airlines is a founding member of the [[Oneworld]] alliance, the third largest airline alliance in the world. Regional service is operated by independent and subsidiary carriers under the brand name [[American Eagle (airline brand)|American Eagle]].{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/american-air-signs-deal-contract-flying-skywest-165209289.html?_esi=1 |title=American Air signs deal to contract out some flying to SkyWest |work=The Associated|publisher=Yahoo! News |date=September 12, 2012 |accessdate=October 3, 2012}} American Airlines and American Eagle operate out of 10 hubs, with [[Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport|Dallas/Fort Worth]] being its largest; handling more than 200 million passengers annually with an average of more than 500,000 passengers daily. American operates its primary maintenance base in [[Tulsa International Airport|Tulsa]] in addition to the maintenance locations at its hubs. As of 2019, the company employs nearly 130,000 people.{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=1579389|title=Company Overview of American Airlines, Inc.|work=Bloomberg|accessdate=June 18, 2019}} == History == {{Main|History of American Airlines}} [[File:N834AA taking off from Sydney Airport July 2018.jpg|thumb|An American Airlines [[Boeing 787-9]] taking off from [[Sydney Airport]] in July 2018]] American Airlines was started in 1930 via a union of more than eighty small airlines.{{cite news|last=Koenig|first=David|title=American Airlines parent seeks Ch. 11 protection|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5gqSFH2Ou81RHegJYXJtAeU9CkyhA?docId=c6952820f230470692fc37e00d9d2d36 |accessdate=December 7, 2011 |newspaper=Google News |date= November 29, 2011|agency=Associated Press|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111204004443/https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5gqSFH2Ou81RHegJYXJtAeU9CkyhA?docId=c6952820f230470692fc37e00d9d2d36|archivedate=December 4, 2011}} The two organizations from which American Airlines was originated were [[Robertson Aircraft Corporation]] and [[Colonial Air Transport]]. The former was first created in Missouri in 1921, with both being merged in 1929 into holding company [[The Aviation Corporation]]. This, in turn, was made in 1930 into an operating company and rebranded as American Airways. In 1934, when new laws and attrition of mail contracts forced many airlines to reorganize, the corporation redid its routes into a connected system and was renamed American Airlines. Between 1970 and 2000, the company grew into being an international carrier, purchasing [[Trans World Airlines]] in 2001.{{Cite web|url=https://money.cnn.com/2001/01/10/deals/amr_twa/|title=TWA to be bought by American - Jan. 10, 2001|website=money.cnn.com|access-date=2019-11-14}} American had a direct role in the development of the [[DC-3]], which resulted from a marathon telephone call from American Airlines CEO [[C. R. Smith]] to Donald Douglas, when Smith persuaded a reluctant Douglas to design a sleeper aircraft based on the [[DC-2]] to replace American's [[Curtiss T-32 Condor II|Curtiss Condor II]] biplanes. (The existing DC-2's cabin was {{convert|66|in|m}} wide, too narrow for side-by-side berths.) Douglas agreed to go ahead with development only after Smith informed him of American's intention to purchase 20 aircraft. The prototype DST ([[Douglas Sleeper Transport]]) first flew on December 17, 1935, (the 32nd anniversary of the [[Wright Brothers]]' flight at Kitty Hawk). Its cabin was {{convert|92|in|m|abbr=on}} wide, and a version with 21 seats instead of the 14–16 sleeping berths of the DST was given the designation DC-3. There was no prototype DC-3; the first DC-3 built followed seven DSTs off the production line and was delivered to American Airlines.Pearcy, Arthur. ''Douglas DC-3 Survivors, Volume 1''. Bourne End, Bucks, UK: Aston Publications, 1987. {{ISBN|0-946627-13-4}}, p. 17 American Airlines inaugurated passenger service on June 26, 1936, with simultaneous flights from [[Newark, New Jersey]], and [[Chicago]], Illinois.Holden, Henry. [http://www.dc3history.org/douglasdc3.html "DC-3 History"]. dc3history.org. Retrieved October 7, 2010. In 2011, due to a downturn in the airline industry, American Airlines' parent company [[AMR Corporation]] filed for bankruptcy protection. In 2013, American Airlines merged with [[US Airways]] but kept the American Airlines name, as it was the better-recognized brand internationally; the combination of the two airlines resulted in the creation of the largest airline in the United States, and ultimately the world.{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/American-Airlines|title=American Airlines – American company|website=Britannica.com}} ==Destinations and hubs== ===Destinations=== {{Main|List of American Airlines destinations}} As of December 2019, American Airlines flies to [[List of American Airlines destinations|95 domestic destinations and 95 international destinations in 55 countries in five continents]], soon to be six when American launches their flight to Casablanca from Philadelphia in June 2020.{{Cite web|url=http://aa.fltmaps.com/en|title=American Airlines Map|website=aa.fltmaps.com|access-date=2019-05-23}} ===Hubs=== American currently operates ten hubs.{{cite web|url=http://news.aa.com/multimedia/default.aspx#factsheets|title=Newsroom – Multimedia – American Airlines Group, Inc|website=news.aa.com}} * [[Charlotte Douglas International Airport|Charlotte]] – Inherited from the merger with [[US Airways]], Charlotte is American's hub for the Southeast and secondary hub to the Caribbean. It also serves as one of American's larger gateways to Europe.{{cite web|url=http://hub.aa.com/en/nr/factsheet/clt |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150224081146/http://hub.aa.com/en/nr/factsheet/clt |url-status=dead |archive-date=February 24, 2015 |title=CLT :: American Airlines Newsroom |website=aa.com |df= }} About 42 million passengers fly through CLT on American every year, or about 115,000 people per day. American has about 91% of the market share at CLT. * [[O'Hare International Airport|Chicago–O'Hare]] – American's hub for the Midwest.{{cite web|url=http://hub.aa.com/en/nr/factsheet/ord |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150224081511/http://hub.aa.com/en/nr/factsheet/ord |url-status=dead |archive-date=February 24, 2015 |title=ORD :: American Airlines Newsroom |website=aa.com |df= }} About 28 million passengers fly on American through O'Hare every year, or about 77,000 people per day. American has about 35% of the market share at O'Hare, making it the airport's second-largest airline after United. * [[Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport|Dallas/Fort Worth]] – American's largest hub for the South.{{cite web|url=http://hub.aa.com/en/nr/factsheet/dfw |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150224081506/http://hub.aa.com/en/nr/factsheet/dfw |url-status=dead |archive-date=February 24, 2015 |title=DFW :: American Airlines Newsroom |website=aa.com |df= }} American currently has about 84% of the market share and flies approximately 57 million passengers through DFW every year, which is about 156,000 people per day, making it the busiest airline at the airport. American's corporate headquarters are also in Fort Worth near the airport. DFW serves as American's primary gateway to Mexico, and secondary gateway to Latin America. * [[Los Angeles International Airport|Los Angeles]] – American's hub for the West Coast and its transpacific gateway.{{cite web|url=http://hub.aa.com/en/nr/factsheet/lax |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150224081300/http://hub.aa.com/en/nr/factsheet/lax |url-status=dead |archive-date=February 24, 2015 |title=LAX :: American Airlines Newsroom |website=aa.com |df= }} About 16.5 million passengers fly through LAX on American every year, or about 45,000 people per day. American has about 19% of the market share at LAX, making it the largest carrier at the airport. * [[Miami International Airport|Miami]] – American's primary Latin American hub.{{cite web|url=http://hub.aa.com/en/nr/factsheet/mia |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150224081305/http://hub.aa.com/en/nr/factsheet/mia |url-status=dead |archive-date=February 24, 2015 |title=MIA :: American Airlines Newsroom |website=Hub.aa.com |accessdate=September 17, 2016 |df= }} About 30 million passengers fly through MIA every year on American, which is about 79,000 people per day. American has about 68% of the market share at Miami International, making it the largest airline at the airport. * [[John F. Kennedy International Airport|New York–JFK]] – American's secondary transatlantic hub.{{cite web|url=http://hub.aa.com/en/nr/factsheet/jfk|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150920003944/http://hub.aa.com/en/nr/factsheet/jfk|url-status=dead|archive-date=September 20, 2015|title=JFK :: American Airlines Newsroom|website=aa.com}} About 7 million passengers fly through JFK on American every year, or about 19,000 people per day. American has about 12% of the market share at JFK, making it the third-largest carrier at the airport behind Delta and JetBlue. JFK also serves as a major connecting point for other [[Oneworld]] carriers. * [[LaGuardia Airport|New York–LaGuardia]] – American's second New York hub.{{cite web|url=http://hub.aa.com/en/nr/factsheet/lga|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150920003951/http://hub.aa.com/en/nr/factsheet/lga|url-status=dead|archive-date=September 20, 2015|title=LGA :: American Airlines Newsroom|website=aa.com}} About 8.5 million passengers fly through LGA on American every year, or about 23,000 people per day. The airport also serves as a base for [[American Airlines Shuttle]]. American has about 27% of the market share at LGA, and is the second-largest carrier behind Delta. * [[Philadelphia International Airport|Philadelphia]] – Inherited from the merger with [[US Airways]], Philadelphia is American's primary transatlantic hub.{{cite web|url=http://hub.aa.com/en/nr/factsheet/phl |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150224081516/http://hub.aa.com/en/nr/factsheet/phl |url-status=dead |archive-date=February 24, 2015 |title=PHL :: American Airlines Newsroom |website=aa.com |df= }} American flies approximately 20.5 million passengers a year through PHL, which is about 56,000 people per day. American has about 70% of the market share at PHL, making it the airport's largest airline. * [[Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport|Phoenix–Sky Harbor]] – Inherited from the merger with [[US Airways]], Phoenix is American's western hub.{{cite web|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/business/airline-industry/20130215-loss-of-a-corporate-headquarters-may-cost-phoenix-jobs-prestige.ece|title=Loss of a corporate headquarters may cost Phoenix jobs, prestige|website=Dallasnews.com|accessdate=September 17, 2016}} American flies approximately 20 million passengers a year through PHX, which is about 55,000 people per day. Currently American has about 46% of the market share at PHX, making it the airport's largest airline. * [[Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport|Washington–National]] – American's hub for the capital of the United States. The airport also serves as a base for [[American Airlines Shuttle]].{{cite web|url=http://hub.aa.com/en/nr/factsheet/2014-dca |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150224081501/http://hub.aa.com/en/nr/factsheet/2014-dca |url-status=dead |archive-date=February 24, 2015 |title=DCA :: American Airlines Newsroom |website=aa.com |df= }} About 12 million passengers fly through DCA on American every year, or about 33,000 people per day. Kingdom PP1367675556.jpg|thumb|American Airlines [[Boeing 777-300ER]] landing at [[London Heathrow Airport]] in 2013.]] As of November 2019, American Airlines operates 940 [[Airbus]], [[Boeing]], and [[Embraer]] aircraft. It is the largest commercial fleet in the world. Over eighty percent of American's aircraft are narrow-bodies, mainly [[Airbus A320 series]] and the [[Boeing 737-800]]. It is the largest [[List of Airbus A320 family operators#Airline operators|A320 series aircraft operator]] in the world, as well as the largest operator of the [[A319]] and [[A321]] variants. It is the fourth-largest [[List of Boeing 737 operators#United States|operator of 737 family aircraft]] and second-largest operator of the 737-800 variant. It also currently operates the Boeing [[757-200]] and [[Embraer 190]], though these are slated for retirement and replacement by the [[Boeing 737 MAX|Boeing 737 MAX 8]] and the [[A320 family|Airbus A320 family]] in coming years. American's wide-body aircraft are a mix of Boeing and Airbus airliners. It is the third-largest [[List of Boeing 787 operators#Current airline operators|operator of the Boeing 787 series]] and the sixth-largest [[List of Boeing 777 operators#Orders and deliveries|operator of the Boeing 777 series]]. It also operates [[Boeing 767]] and [[Airbus A330]] aircraft, with most slated for retirement in favor of additional [[Boeing 787]] aircraft.{{cite web | url = http://theflight.info/american_airlines/ | title = American Airlines aircraft fleet | archive-url = https://archive.today/20181003141132/http://theflight.info/american_airlines/ | archive-date = October 3, 2018 | url-status=live | access-date = May 13, 2019 | df = mdy-all }} American Airlines exclusively ordered Boeing aircraft throughout the 2000s.{{cite news |last1=Ruiz |first1=Rebecca |title=Boeing Was ‘Go, Go, Go’ to Beat Airbus With the 737 Max |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/03/23/business/boeing-737-max-crash.html |accessdate=27 November 2019 |work=New York Times |date=23 March 2019}} This strategy shifted on July 20, 2011, when American announced the largest combined aircraft order in history for 460 narrow-body jets including 260 [[Airbus A320|Airbus 320 Series]].{{cite press release |url= http://news.aa.com/press-releases/press-release-details/2011/AMR-Corporation-Announces-Largest-Aircraft-Order-in-History-With-Boeing-and-Airbus/default.aspx |title= AMR Corporation Announces Largest Aircraft Order in History With Boeing and Airbus |publisher= American Airlines |date= July 20, 2011}} Additional Airbus aircraft joined the fleet in 2013 upon merger with US Airways, which operated Airbus aircraft almost exclusively.{{cite web |title=US Airways Fleet |url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/US_Airways_fleet |website=wikipedia.org |accessdate=27 November 2019}}{{Circular A321T business class (11424746783).jpg |caption2 = First and business class seats on an [[Airbus 321|A321]] Transcontinental (top and bottom, respectively) }} ;Flagship First Flagship First is American's international First Class product. It is offered only on the airline's Boeing 777-300ERs. The seats are fully lie-flat and offer direct aisle access in a 1-2-1 reverse herringbone configuration. As with the airline's other premium cabins, Flagship First offers wider food and beverage options, larger seats, and more amenities at certain airports, e.g., lounge access.{{citation needed|date=January 2019}} ;Flagship Business Flagship Business is a premium cabin offered on some Boeing 757-200s and all Airbus A330-200s, Airbus A330-300s, Boeing 767-300ERs, Boeing 777-200ERs, Boeing 777-300ERs, Boeing 787-8s, and Boeing 787-9s. All Flagship Business seats are fully lie-flat.{{cite web|url=https://www.aa.com/i18n/travel-info/experience/seats/flagship-business-international.jsp|title=Flagship Business - International|publisher=American Airlines|accessdate=January 27, 2019}}{{Better source|date=January 2019}} Only the Boeing 757-200 does not offer direct aisle access from each seat.{{citation needed|date=January 2019}} ; ;Transcontinental American has dedicated 17 [[Airbus A321]]s (A321T) in its fleet for the specific use of flying transcontinental routes between [[John F. Kennedy International Airport|New York JFK]] and [[Los Angeles International Airport|Los Angeles]], New York JFK and [[San Francisco International Airport|San Francisco]], and [[Logan International Airport|Boston]] and Los Angeles. These aircraft offer two premium cabins, Flagship First and Flagship Business, which are unique among domestic mainline aircraft in American's fleet. Both cabins feature lie-flat seats; Flagship First also includes direct aisle access from each seat.{{citation needed|date=January 2019}} ;Domestic First Class First Class is offered on all domestic mainline aircraft, as well as regional aircraft with more than 50 seats. When such aircraft are used on flights to international destinations including Canada, Mexico, Central America, and the Caribbean, the First Class cabin is branded as Business Class. Seats range from {{convert|19|-|21|in|cm}} in width and have {{convert|37|-|42|in|cm}} of pitch.{{cite web|url=http://www.seatguru.com/airlines/American_Airlines/fleetinfo.php|title=American Airlines Planes and Seat Maps|website=Tripadvisor.com|accessdate=May 24, 2015}}{{Failed verification|date=January 2019}} Dining options include free snacks, beverages, and alcohol on all flights, with three-course meals offered on flights {{convert|900|mi|km}} or longer (some routes under 900 miles also offer meal service).{{cite web|url=http://www.aa.com/i18n/travelInformation/duringFlight/dining/premium-cabin.jsp|title=First and Business Class Dining|website=Aa.com|accessdate=May 24, 2015|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150520212859/http://www.aa.com/i18n/travelInformation/duringFlight/dining/premium-cabin.jsp|archivedate=May 20, 2015|df=}}{{Better source|date=January 2019}} ;Premium Economy On December 9, 2015, American announced a new Premium Economy cabin for most long-haul widebody aircraft. The cabin debuted on the airline's Boeing 787-9s in late 2016 and is also available on Boeing 777-200s and -300s, some Boeing 787-8s, and Airbus A330-200s. Premium Economy seats are wider than seats in Main Cabin (American's economy cabin) and provide more amenities: Premium Economy customers get two free [https://www.baggagecircle.com/knowledge-base/american-airlines-carry-on-baggage-policy-2020-2021/ checked bags], priority boarding, and enhanced food and drink service including free alcohol. This product made American Airlines the first U.S. carrier to offer a four-cabin aircraft.{{cite web|url=http://upgrd.com/blogs/doublewidesfly/american-airlines-premium-economy-the-only-north-american-carrier-to-offer-a-4-cabin-aircraft.html|title=American Airlines Premium Economy – The Only North American Carrier to Offer a 4 Cabin Aircraft|website=upgrd.com}}{{Better source|date=January 2019}} ;Main Cabin Extra American's economy plus product (not to be confused with premium economy), Main Cabin Extra, is available on most of the mainline fleet and [[American Eagle (airline brand)|American Eagle]] regional aircraft with more than 50 seats. Main Cabin Extra seats include greater pitch than is available in Main Cabin, along with free alcoholic beverages.{{cite web|url=https://www.aa.com/i18n/travel-info/experience/seats/main-cabin-extra.jsp|title=Main Cabin Extra|publisher=American Airlines|accessdate=January 27, 2019}}{{Better source|date=January 2019}} American retained Main Cabin Extra when the new Premium Economy product entered service in late 2016.{{Better source|date=January 2019}} ;Main Cabin Main Cabin is American's economy product, and is found on all mainline and regional aircraft in its fleet. Seats range from {{convert|17|-|18.5|in|cm}} in width and have {{convert|30|-|32|in|cm}} of pitch.{{cite web|title=American Airlines planes and seat maps|url=https://www.seatguru.com/airlines/American_Airlines/fleetinfo.php|website=tripadvisor.com|accessdate=September 17, 2016}}{{Failed verification|date=January 2019}} American Airlines marketed increased legroom in economy class as "More Room Throughout Coach", also referred to as "MRTC", starting in February 2000.{{cite web|url=https://www.aa.com/i18n/customer-service/about-us/history-of-american-airlines.jsp |title=History of American Airlines – About us – American Airlines |publisher=American Airlines |date= |accessdate=September 17, 2016}}{{Better source|date=January 2019}} Two rows of economy class seats were removed on Boeing 737 and McDonnell Douglas MD-80 aircraft.{{cite web|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/travel/news/2004-10-20-more-seats_x.htm |title=USATODAY.com – American Airlines squeezes passengers in tighter to make money |website=Usatoday30.usatoday.com |date=October 21, 2004 |accessdate=September 17, 2016}} Amid financial losses, this scheme was discontinued in 2004.{{cite web|url=http://business.time.com/2012/03/02/american-airlines-offering-more-legroom-for-a-price/|title=American Airlines Offering More Legroom … For a Price|first=Josh|last=Sanburn|website=Business.time.com}} On some routes, American also offers [[Basic Economy]], the airline's lowest main cabin fare. Basic Economy is located in the main cabin but comes with restrictions. These restrictions include waiting until check-in for a seat assignment, no upgrades or refunds, and boarding in the last group.{{cite web|title=Basic Economy|url=https://www.aa.com/i18n/travel-info/experience/seats/basic-economy.jsp|website=American Airlines|publisher=American Airlines}}{{Better source|date=January 2019}} In May 2017, American announced it would be adding more seats to some of its Boeing 737 MAX jetliners and reducing overall legroom in the basic economy class. The last three rows will lose {{convert|2|in|cm}}, going from the current {{convert|31|in|cm}} to {{convert|29|in|cm}}. The remainder of the economy cabin will have {{convert|30|in|cm}} of legroom.{{cite news |last=Ostrower |first=Jon |title=American Airlines is cutting more legroom in economy class |work=[[CNN]] Money |publisher=Cable News Network |date=May 3, 2017|url=https://money.cnn.com/2017/05/02/news/companies/american-airlines-legroom/index.html }} == Reward programs == === AAdvantage === {{Main|AAdvantage}} AAdvantage is the [[frequent flyer program]] for American Airlines. It was launched on May 1, 1981, and it remains the largest frequent flyer program with over 67 million members as of 2011. Miles accumulated in the program allow members to redeem tickets, upgrade service class, or obtain free or discounted car rentals, hotel stays, merchandise, or other products and services through partners. The most active members, based on the amount and price of travel booked, are designated AAdvantage Gold, AAdvantage Platinum, AAdvantage Platinum Pro, and AAdvantage Executive Platinum elite members, with privileges such as separate check-in, priority upgrade and standby processing, or free upgrades. They also receive similar privileges from AA's partner airlines, particularly those in [[oneworld]].[http://www.aa.com/aa/i18nForward.do?p=/AAdvantage/partners/airlines/oneWorld.jsp#elite oneworld Alliance] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081220083602/http://www.aa.com/aa/i18nForward.do?p=%2FAAdvantage%2Fpartners%2Fairlines%2FoneWorld.jsp#elite |date=December 20, 2008 }}. Aa.com (October 1, 2010). Retrieved on November 4, 2010.{{Better source|date=January 2019}} AAdvantage co-branded credit cards are also available and offer other benefits. The cards are issued by CitiCards, a subsidiary of [[Citigroup]], and [[Barclaycard]] in the United States, by [[MBNA]] in the United Kingdom, by [[Butterfield Bank]] and [[Scotiabank]] in the Caribbean, and by [[Banco Santander]] in Brazil.{{citation needed|date=January 2019}} AAdvantage allows one-way redemption, starting at 5,000 miles.{{cite web|url=http://www.aa.com/i18n/disclaimers/aadvantageAllPartnerChart.jsp|title=oneworld and Other Airline Award Chart|last=|first=|date=December 18, 2013|website=Aa.com|archiveurl=https://archive.today/20131218060310/http://www.aa.com/i18n/disclaimers/aadvantageAllPartnerChart.jsp|archivedate=December 18, 2013|url-status=dead|access-date=}}{{Better source|date=January 2019}} === Admirals Club === The Admirals Club was conceived by AA president C.R. Smith as a marketing promotion shortly after he was made an honorary [[Texas Ranger Division|Texas Ranger]]. Inspired by the [[Kentucky colonel]]s and other [[Title of honor|honorary title]] designations, Smith decided to make particularly valued passengers "admirals" of the "Flagship fleet" (AA called its aircraft "Flagships" at the time).{{cite web|last1=Li |first1=Lucy |title=Ultimate Guide to Admirals Club |url=http://www.loungebuddy.com/admirals-club-ultimate-guide/ |website=LoungeBuddy |publisher=LoungeBuddy, Inc |accessdate=July 20, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150906212847/http://www.loungebuddy.com/admirals-club-ultimate-guide/ |archivedate=September 6, 2015 |url-status=live |df= }}{{Better source|date=January 2019}} The list of Admirals included many celebrities, politicians, and other VIPs, as well as more "ordinary" customers who had been particularly loyal to the airline.{{citation needed|date=January 2019}} There was no physical Admirals Club until shortly after the opening of LaGuardia Airport. During the airport's construction, New York Mayor Fiorello LaGuardia had an upper-level lounge set aside for press conferences and business meetings. At one such press conference, he noted that the entire terminal was being offered for lease to airline tenants; after a reporter asked whether the lounge would be leased as well, LaGuardia replied that it would, and a vice president of AA immediately offered to lease the premises. The airline then procured a liquor license and began operating the lounge as the "Admirals Club" in 1939.{{citation needed|date=December 2013}} The second Admirals Club opened at Washington National Airport. Because it was illegal to sell alcohol in Virginia at the time, the club contained refrigerators for the use of its members, so they could store their liquor at the airport.{{citation needed|date=December 2013}} For many years, membership in the Admirals Club (and most other airline lounges) was by the airline's invitation. After a passenger sued for discrimination,{{cite news|title=Toward Equality for VIPs |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,836046,00.html?iid=chix-sphere |work=TIME |date=July 15, 1966 |accessdate=January 26, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090114112519/http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0%2C9171%2C836046%2C00.html?iid=chix-sphere |archivedate=January 14, 2009 |url-status=live |df= }} the Club (and most other airline lounges) switched to a paid membership program.{{citation needed|date=January 2019}} === Flagship Lounge === Though affiliated with the Admirals Club and staffed by many of the same employees, the Flagship Lounge is a separate lounge specifically designed for customers flying in First Class and Business Class on international flights and transcontinental domestic flights, as well as AAdvantage Concierge Key, Executive Platinum, Platinum Pro, and Platinum, as well as Oneworld Emerald and Sapphire frequent flyers. As of May 2019, Flagship Lounges are located at five airports: New York–JFK,{{cite web|url=http://fortune.com/go/luxury/american-airlines-flaship-lounge-jfk-airport/|last=Tkaczyk|first=Christopher |date=May 25, 2017|title=An Inside Look at the New American Airlines Flagship Lounge at JFK Airport|work=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]|accessdate=May 14, 2019}} Chicago-O'Hare,{{cite web|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/chicago/news/2017/09/13/american-airlines-rolls-out-flashy-flagship-lounge.html|last=Lazare |first=Lewis |date=September 13, 2017|title=American Airlines rolls out flashy Flagship Lounge at O'Hare Airport (Photos)|work=[[Chicago Business Journal]]|accessdate=May 14, 2019}} Miami International,{{cite web|url=https://www.sun-sentinel.com/business/fl-bz-mia-new-american-flagship-lounge-20171116-story.html|last=Satchell|first= Arlene|date=November 16, 2017|title=American's Flagship Lounge at MIA opens Tuesday for first-class, business travelers|work=[[Sun-Sentinel]]|accessdate=May 14, 2019}} Los Angeles,{{cite web|url=https://www.nzherald.co.nz/travel/news/article.cfm?c_id=7&objectid=12193870|last=Jurgens |first=Jane |date=January 23, 2019|title=Lounge Check: American Airlines Flagship Business Class lounge at LAX|work=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|accessdate=May 14, 2019}} and Dallas/Fort Worth.{{cite web|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/dallas/news/2019/05/14/american-airlines-flagship-lounge-dfw-airport.html?|last=Hoopfer |first=Evan |date=May 14, 2019|title=Shower in an airport? See inside American's swanky new DFW lounge|work=[[American City Business Journals#Dallas Business Journal|Dallas Business Journal]]|accessdate=May 14, 2019}} Flagship Lounges are planned for London-Heathrow and Philadelphia. == Corporate affairs == ===Ownership and structure=== American Airlines, Inc. is publicly traded through its parent company, [[American Airlines Group]] Inc., under NASDAQ: AAL {{NASDAQ|AAL}}, with a market capitalization of about $12 billion as of 2019, and is included in the [[S&P 500 Index|S&P 500 index]]. American Eagle is a network of seven regional carriers that operate under a codeshare and service agreement with American, operating flights to destinations in the United States, Canada, the Caribbean and Mexico. The airline considered developing a new headquarters in [[Irving, Texas]], on the old [[Texas Stadium]] site, before deciding to keep the headquarters in Fort Worth. === Corporate identity === [[File:American Airlines logo.svg|thumb|American Airlines' fourth logo, used from 1967 to January 16, 2013]] ==== Logo ==== In 1931, Goodrich Murphy, an American employee, designed the AA logo.{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/2015/05/tales-era-airlines-knew-good-design/|title=Tales From an Era When Airlines Knew Good Design |website=Wired.com |accessdate=May 22, 2015}} The logo was redesigned by [[Massimo Vignelli]] in 1967.{{cite web |url=http://www.vignelli.com/home/identity/aa.html |title=Vignelli Associates About the AA Logo |website=Vignelli.com |accessdate=December 2, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171201175513/http://vignelli.com/home/identity/aa.html |archive-date=December 1, 2017 |url-status=dead }}{{cite web|url=http://www.logosdesigners.com/#massimo-vignelli|title=iconic logo designers|website=logosdesigners.com|accessdate=April 3, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100124021004/http://www.logosdesigners.com/#massimo-vignelli|archive-date=January 24, 2010|url-status=dead|df=}} Thirty years later, in 1997, American Airlines was able to make its logo Internet-compatible by buying the domain AA.com. ''AA'' is also American's two-letter [[IATA]] [[airline codes|airline designator]].{{cite web |title=Current Airline Members |url=https://www.iata.org/about/members/Pages/airline-list.aspx?All=true |website=Iata.org |accessdate=February 5, 2019 |language=English}} On January 17, 2013, American launched a new rebranding and marketing campaign with FutureBrand dubbed, "A New American". This included a new logo replacing the logo used since 1967. American Airlines calls the new logo the "Flight Symbol, incorporating the eagle, star, and the letter “A” of the classic logo.{{cite web|url=https://www.aa.com/newamerican?anchorLocation=HomePageHero1&reportedTitle=Becoming%20a%20new%20American&reportedPosition=0&url=undefined&_locale=en_US&repositoryName=undefined&repositoryId=undefined |title=Becoming a new American |website=Aa.com |date= |accessdate=March 6, 2013}}{{better source|date=January 2019}} American Airlines faced difficulty obtaining copyright registration for their 2013 logo. On June 3, 2016, American Airlines sought to register it with the [[United States Copyright Office]],{{cite web|last1=Zaller Rowland|first1=Catherine|title=Re: Second Request for Reconsideration for Refusal to Register American Airlines Flight Symbol; Correspondence ID: 1-28H4ZFK; SR#: 1-3537494381|url=https://www.copyright.gov/rulings-filings/review-board/docs/american-airlines-flight-symbol.pdf|date=January 8, 2018|website=Copyright.gov|publisher=[[United States Copyright Office]]|accessdate=January 26, 2018}} but in October of that year, the Copyright Office ruled that the logo was ineligible for copyright protection, as it did not pass the [[threshold of originality]], and was thus in the [[public domain]]. American requested that the Copyright Office reconsider, but on January 8, 2018, the Copyright Office affirmed its initial determination.{{cite web|title=US Copyright Office Says What We're All Thinking: American Airlines Lacks Creativity – One Mile at a Time|url=http://onemileatatime.boardingarea.com/2018/01/25/american-airlines-copyright/|website=One Mile at a Time|date=January 25, 2018}} After American Airlines submitted additional materials, the Copyright Office reversed its decision on December 7, 2018, and ruled that the logo contained enough creativity to merit copyright protection.{{Cite web |url=https://www.copyright.gov/rulings-filings/review-board/docs/american-airlines.pdf |title=Re: Registration Decision Regarding American Airlines Flight Symbol; Correspondence ID 1-28H4ZFK; SR 1-3537494381 |date=December 7, 2018 |publisher=[[United States Copyright Office]] |access-date=June 23, 2019}} ==== Aircraft livery ==== American's early [[aircraft livery|liveries]] varied widely, but a common livery was adopted in the 1930s, featuring an [[eagle]] painted on the fuselage.{{ cite web | url = http://www.airlinesanddestinations.com/aircraft/american-airlines-unveils-new-logo-and-livery/ | title = American Airlines Unveils New Logo and Livery | website = Airlines and Destinations | date = January 17, 2013 | accessdate = July 26, 2017 }} The eagle became a symbol of the company and inspired the name of [[Envoy Air|American Eagle Airlines]]. Propeller aircraft featured an [[international orange]] lightning bolt running down the length of the fuselage, which was replaced by a simpler orange stripe with the introduction of jets.{{citation needed|date=January 2019}} [[File:American Airlines Astrojet N951AA.jpg|thumb|A Boeing 737 in the Astrojet livery]] In the late 1960s, American commissioned designer [[Massimo Vignelli]] to develop a new livery. The original design called for a red, white, and blue stripe on the fuselage, and a simple "AA" logo, without an eagle, on the tail; instead, Vignelli created a highly stylized eagle, which remained the company's logo until January 16, 2013. In 1999, American painted a new [[Boeing 757]] (N679AN) in its 1959 international orange livery. One [[Boeing 777]] and one Boeing 757 were painted in standard livery with a pink ribbon on the sides and the tail, in support of [[Susan G. Komen for the Cure]]. One Boeing 757 is painted with a yellow ribbon on the tailfin on the aircraft and the side of the body says "Flagship Freedom". American Eagle, the airline's regional airline has the same special livery on ERJ-145 aircraft.{{citation needed|date=January 2019}} [[File:AA Flagship Freedom.JPG|thumb|left|AA "Flagship Freedom" [[Boeing 757-200]], labeled with a "[[Yellow ribbon|yellow awareness ribbon]]" symbol, representing support of the [[United States Armed Forces]] overseas operations.]] On January 17, 2013, American unveiled a new livery.{{cite news |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/business/breaking/chi-american-airlines-livery-20130117,0,198977.story |title=American Airlines unveils new logo, livery |work=Chicago Tribune |date=January 17, 2013 |accessdate=January 17, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130217030650/http://www.chicagotribune.com/business/breaking/chi-american-airlines-livery-20130117,0,198977.story |archive-date=February 17, 2013 |url-status=dead }} Before then, American had been the only major U.S. airline to leave most of its aircraft surfaces unpainted. This was because C. R. Smith would not say he liked painted aircraft and refused to use any liveries that involved painting the entire plane. Robert "Bob" Crandall later justified the distinctive natural metal finish by noting that less paint reduced the aircraft's weight, thus saving on fuel costs.{{cite web|url=http://industry.bnet.com/travel/1000148/paint-vs-bare-metal-on-airplanes/ |title=Delta, Air Canada Among Carriers Weighing Benefit of Paint Stripping |website=Industry.bnet.com |date=October 8, 2008 |accessdate=December 2, 2011}} [[File:US Airways A319-112 LAS N717UW.jpg|thumb|Airbus A319 of US Airways wearing [[Carolina Panthers]] livery]] [[File:N921NN B737-823W American Al YVR 24JUL13 (9362686624).jpg|thumb|Boeing 737 aircraft N921NN, the final aircraft delivered to American in the polished aluminum livery, retained as a heritage aircraft.]] In January 2013, American launched a new rebranding and marketing campaign dubbed, "The New American". In addition to a new logo, American Airlines introduced a new livery for its fleet. The airline calls the new livery and branding "a clean and modern update". The current design features an abstract American flag on the tail, along with a silver-painted fuselage, as a throw-back to the old livery. The new design was painted by [[Leading Edge Aviation Services]] in [[California]].{{cite web|last=Ahles |first=Andrea |url=http://www.star-telegram.com/2013/01/17/4556563/american-airlines-shows-off-new.html |title=Star-Telegram 18 January 2013: "American Airlines shows off new look for new era" |website=Star-telegram.com |date=January 18, 2013 |accessdate=January 29, 2014 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130310095631/http://www.star-telegram.com/2013/01/17/4556563/american-airlines-shows-off-new.html |archivedate=March 10, 2013 }} Doug Parker, the incoming CEO indicated that the new livery could be short-lived, stating that "maybe we need to do something slightly different than that ... The only reason this is an issue now is because they just did it right in the middle, which kind of makes it confusing, so that gives us an opportunity, actually, to decide if we are going to do something different because we have so many airplanes to paint".King, Eric. (March 28, 2013) [http://www.nbcdfw.com/news/business/American-Airlines-New-Livery-Soon-Could-Become-Its-Old-Look-200532901.html American Airline's New Livery Soon Could Become Its Old Look | NBC 5 Dallas-Fort Worth]. Nbcdfw.com. Retrieved on July 18, 2013. The current logo and livery have had mixed criticism, with ''[[Design Shack]]'' editor Joshua Johnson writing that they 'boldly and proudly communicate the concepts of American pride and freedom wrapped into a shape that instantly makes you think about an airplane',{{cite web |last1=Johnson |first1=Joshua |title=Check Out the New American Airlines Logo |url=https://designshack.net/articles/graphics/check-out-the-new-american-airlines-logo/ |website=Design Shack |accessdate=June 11, 2019 |date=January 23, 2013}} and ''[http://www.askthepilot.com/ AskThePilot.com]'' author Patrick Smith describing the logo as 'a linoleum knife poking through a shower curtain'.{{cite web |last1=Smith |first1=Patrick |title=The New American Airlines Livery |url=http://www.askthepilot.com/american-to-keep-new-livery/ |website=AskThePilot.com |accessdate=June 11, 2019 |date=January 6, 2014}} Later in January 2013, [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] asked the designer of the 1968 American Airlines logo ([[Massimo Vignelli]]) on his opinion over the rebranding.{{cite news |last1=Mayo |first1=Keenan |title=Q&A: Original American Airlines Designer Massimo Vignelli on the Redesigned Logo |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2013-01-18/q-and-a-original-american-airlines-designer-massimo-vignelli-on-the-redesigned-logo |accessdate=August 7, 2019 |work=Bloomberg.com |publisher=Bloomberg L.P. |date=January 19, 2013 |format=Web}} In the end, American let its employees decide the new livery's fate. On an internal website for employees, American posted two options, one the new livery and one a modified version of the old livery. All of the [[American Airlines Group]] employees (including US Airways and other affiliates) were able to vote.{{cite web | url = https://www.dallasnews.com/business/airlines/2013/12/16/doug-parker-to-let-american-airlines-employees-decide-whether-to-keep-the-new-aa-tail | title = Doug Parker to let American Airlines employees decide whether to keep the new AA tail | website = [[Dallas News]] | last = Maxon | first = Terry | date = December 2013 | accessdate = July 26, 2017 }} American ultimately decided to keep the new look. Parker announced that American would keep a US Airways and America West heritage aircraft in the fleet, with plans to add a heritage TWA aircraft and a heritage American plane with the old livery.{{cite web | url = http://www.nbcdfw.com/news/business/American-Airlines-Employees-Vote-to-Keep-New-Livery-238487381.html | title = American Airlines Employees Vote to Keep New Livery | website = [[NBC]] | last = Heinz | first = Frank | date = January 2, 2014 | accessdate = July 26, 2017 }} As of September 2019, American has heritage aircraft for Piedmont, PSA, America West, US Airways, Reno Air, TWA, and AirCal in their fleet.{{Cite web|url=https://apex.aero/2015/12/03/heritage-livery-flies-again-american-airlines-retro-rollout|title=[PHOTOS] Heritage Livery Flies Again in American Airlines’ Retro Rollout|date=2015-12-03|website=APEX {{!}} Airline Passenger Experience|access-date=2019-09-30}} They also have two AA branded heritage 737-800 aircraft, an AstroJet N905NN,{{Cite web|url=https://airlinegeeks.com/2017/06/05/photos-american-rolls-out-new-astrojet-themed-boeing-737-800/|title=Photos: American Rolls out New AstroJet-Themed Boeing 737-800|last=Ewing|first=Ryan|date=2017-06-05|website=AirlineGeeks.com|language=en-US|access-date=2019-09-30}} and the polished aluminum livery used from 1967 to 2013, N921NN.{{Cite web|url=https://airlinegeeks.com/2017/12/14/american-quietly-adds-new-polished-aluminum-retro-livery-to-a-boeing-737-800/|title=American Quietly Adds Polished Aluminum Retro Livery to a Boeing 737-800|last=Ewing|first=Ryan|date=2017-12-14|website=AirlineGeeks.com|language=en-US|access-date=2019-09-30}} === Worker relations === The main representatives of key groups of employees are: * The [[Allied Pilots Association]] is an in-house union which represents the nearly 15,000 American Airlines pilots; it was created in 1963 after the pilots left the [[Air Line Pilots Association]] (ALPA).{{cite web|url=http://www.alliedpilots.org/Public/AboutAPA/Background/background.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=February 5, 2016 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160204003305/https://www.alliedpilots.org/Public/AboutAPA/Background/background.asp |archivedate=February 4, 2016 |df= }} However the majority of American Eagle pilots are ALPA members.{{Cite web|url=http://www.alpa.org/en/about-alpa/our-pilot-groups/pilot-groups/envoy|title=Envoy Air – ALPA|website=alpa.org|access-date=October 26, 2016}} * The [[Association of Professional Flight Attendants]] represents American Airlines flight attendants, including former USAirways flight attendants.{{cite web|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/business/airline-industry/20141218-american-airlines-flight-attendants-to-get-bigger-pay-raises-after-all.ece|title=American Airlines flight attendants to get bigger pay raises after all|website=Dallasnews.com|accessdate=September 17, 2016}} * Flight attendants at wholly owned Regional Carriers (Envoy, Piedmont and PSA) are all represented by [http://www.afacwa.org/ Association of Flight Attendants – Communications Workers of America] (AFA-CWA). US Airways flight attendants were active members of AFA-CWA before the merger, and they are honorary lifetime members. AFA-CWA is the largest flight attendant union in the industry.{{citation needed|date=January 2019}} * The [[Transport Workers Union of America|Transport Workers Union-International Association of Machinists alliance]] (TWU-IAM) represents the majority of American Airlines employed fleet service agents, mechanics and other ground workers.{{cite web|url=http://www.star-telegram.com/news/business/aviation/sky-talk-blog/article36302475.html|title=American CEO says contract proposals to ground workers to have "double-digit" pay increases|website=Star-telegram.com|accessdate=September 17, 2016}} * American's customer service and gate employees belong to the [[Communications Workers of America]]/[[International Brotherhood of Teamsters]] Passenger Service Association.{{cite web|url=http://aviationblog.dallasnews.com/2015/11/american-airlines-gate-agents-approve-a-new-labor-contract.html/|title=American Airlines customer service and gate agents approve new labor contract|last =Jean|first =Sheryl|website=Airline Biz Blog}} == Concerns and conflicts == === Environmental violations === Between October 1993 to July 1998, American Airlines was repeatedly cited for using high-sulfur fuel in motor vehicles at 10 major airports around the country, a violation of the [[Clean Air Act (United States)|Clean Air Act]].{{cite web|title=American Airlines Will Make Clean Air Improvements at Logan Airport Reports to EPA the Use of Illegal High Sulfur Fuel in Motor Vehicles|url=http://epa.gov/NE/pr/1999/072099b.html |website=[[United States Environmental Protection Agency]]|date=July 19, 1999|accessdate=January 25, 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070707175156/http://epa.gov/ne/pr/1999/072099b.html|archivedate=July 7, 2007}} === Lifetime AAirpass === Since 1981, as a means of creating revenue in a period of loss-making, American Airlines had offered a [[AAirpass|lifetime pass]] of unlimited travel, for the initial cost of $250,000. This entitled the pass holder to fly anywhere in the world. 28 were sold. However, after some time, the airline realised they were making losses on the tickets, with the ticketholders costing them up to $1 million each. Ticketholders were booking large amounts of flights, and some ticketholders flying interstate for lunch or flying to London multiple times a month. AA raised the cost of the lifetime pass to $3 million, and then finally stopped offering it in 2003. AA then used litigation to cancel two of the lifetime offers, saying the passes "had been terminated due to fraudulent activity".{{cite web|title=‘Free’quent flier has wings clipped after American Airlines takes away his unlimited pass|url=https://nypost.com/2012/05/13/freequent-flier-has-wings-clipped-after-american-airlines-takes-away-his-unlimited-pass/ |publisher=New York Post|date=May 13, 2012|accessdate=October 20, 2019}} === Cabin fume events === * In 1988, on American Airlines Flight 132's approach into Nashville, flight attendants notified the cockpit that there was smoke in the cabin. The flight crew in the cockpit ignored the warning, as on a prior flight, a [[fume event]] had occurred due to a problem with the [[auxiliary power unit]]. However, the smoke on Flight 132 was caused by improperly packaged hazardous materials. According to the [[National Transportation Safety Board|NTSB]] inquiry, the cockpit crew persistently refused to acknowledge that there was a serious threat to the aircraft or the passengers, even after they were told that floor was becoming soft and passengers had to be reseated. As a result, the aircraft was not evacuated immediately on landing, exposing the crew and passengers to the threat of smoke and fire longer than necessary.{{cite web|url=https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/a02a/6b1ff0725d682e3ab0fa55681a1db46af4ad.pdf|title=Chute, Rebecca D., and Earl L. Winter. "Cockpit-cabin communication: II. Shall we tell the pilots?." The International Journal of Aviation Psychology 6.3 (1996): 211-231.|website=Pdfs.semanticscholar.org|accessdate=February 23, 2019}}{{cite web|url=http://flightsafety.org/asw/jul12/asw_jul12_p32-35.pdf|title=Cross, Jamie. "Sources of friction." AeroSafety world 7.online (2012): 32-35.|website=Flightsafety.org|accessdate=February 23, 2019}} * On April 11, 2007, toxic smoke and oil fumes leaked into the aircraft cabin as American Airlines Flight 843 taxied to the gate. A flight attendant who was present in the cabin subsequently filed a lawsuit against Boeing, stating that she was diagnosed with neurotoxic disorder due to her exposure to the fumes, which caused her to experience memory loss, tremors, and severe headaches. She settled with the company in 2011.[http://www.nbcnews.com/id/44777304/ns/travel-news/t/boeing-suit-settlement-stirs-jetliner-air-safety-debate/#.XFqZYVUzaUk Boeing suit settlement stirs jetliner air safety debate], NBC news, October 6, 2011 * In 2009, Mike Holland, deputy chairman for radiation and environmental issues at the [[Allied Pilots Association]] and an American Airlines pilot, said that the pilot union had started alerting pilots of the danger of contaminated [[bleed air]], including contacting crew members that the union thinks were exposed to contamination based on maintenance records and pilot logs.[https://zembla.bnnvara.nl/pdf/wsj_fume_events.pdf Nassauer, Sarah. "Up in the Air: New Worries About ‘Fume Events’ on Planes."] The Wall Street Journal (2009). * In a January 2017 incident on American Airlines Flight 1896, seven flight attendants were hospitalized after a strange odor was detected in the cabin. The Airbus A330 involved subsequently underwent a "thorough maintenance inspection," having been involved in three fume events in three months.[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/news/fume-incident-hospitalises-american-airlines-crew-and-raises-questions-over-safety-of-cabin-air/ ‘Fume event’ hospitalises American Airlines crew in Airlines staffers hospitalized after noticing 'odor' on plane], FOX News, January 10, 2019 === Discrimination complaints === On October 24, 2017, the [[NAACP]] issued a travel advisory for American Airlines urging [[African Americans]] to "exercise caution" when traveling with the airline. The NAACP issued the advisory after four incidents. In one incident, a black woman was moved from First Class to coach while her white traveling companion was allowed to remain in First Class. In another incident, a black man was forced to give up his seats after being confronted by two unruly white passengers.[https://www.pbs.org/newshour/nation/the-naacp-issues-travel-advisory-for-american-airlines-warning-black-passengers-of-disturbing-incidents The NAACP issues travel advisory for American Airlines, warning black passengers of ‘disturbing incidents’], PBS, October 25, 2017 According to the NAACP, while they did receive complaints on other airlines, most of their complaints in the year prior to their advisory were on American Airlines.[https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/2017/10/25/naacp-most-complaints-american-airlines-what-can-brands-learn/800300001/ NAACP: Most complaints about American Airlines. What can brands learn?], USA Today, October 25, 2017 In July 2018, the NAACP lifted their travel advisory saying that American has made improvements to mitigate discrimination and unsafe treatment of African Americans.[https://www.pbs.org/newshour/nation/naacp-lifts-travel-advisory-against-american-airlines NAACP lifts travel advisory against American Airlines], PBS, July 17, 2018 == Accidents and incidents == {{Main|List of American Airlines accidents and incidents}} As of March 2019, the airline has had almost sixty aircraft [[hull loss]]es, beginning with the crash of an American Airways [[Ford Trimotor|Ford 5-AT-C Trimotor]] in August 1931.{{cite web|url=http://aviation-safety.net/database/operator/airline.php?var=9366 |title=American Airways safety occurrences |website=[[Aviation Safety Network]] |publisher=[[Flight Safety Foundation]] |access-date=January 3, 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://aviation-safety.net/database/operator/airline.php?var=6516 |title=American Airlines safety occurrences |website=[[Aviation Safety Network]] |publisher=[[Flight Safety Foundation]] |access-date=January 3, 2018}} Of these most were propeller driven aircraft, including three [[Lockheed L-188 Electra]] turboprop aircraft (of which one, the crash in 1959 of [[American Airlines Flight 320|Flight 320]], resulted in fatalities). The two accidents with the highest fatalities in both the airline's and U.S. aviation history were [[American Airlines Flight 191|Flight 191]] in 1979 and [[American Airlines Flight 587|Flight 587]] in 2001.{{Cite web|url=https://aviation-safety.net/database/country/country.php?id=N|title=Aviation Safety Network > ASN Aviation Safety Database > Geographical regions > United States of America air safety profile|last=Ranter|first=Harro|website=aviation-safety.net|access-date=2019-07-26}} On December 20, 1995, [[American Airlines Flight 965|Flight 965]] crashed into a mountain in Buga, Colombia, killing 151 out of the 155 passengers and all eight crew members. The aircraft was a Boeing 757-223 (registration N651AA). It was on approach to Cali, Colombia when it veered off course and crashed into the terrain. Two aircraft were hijacked and destroyed in the [[September 11 attacks]]: [[American Airlines Flight 11|Flight 11]] crashed into the north facade of the [[One World Trade Center|North Tower]] of the [[World Trade Center (1973–2001)|World Trade Center]], and [[Flight 77]] crashed into [[the Pentagon]]; both were bound for [[Los Angeles International Airport|LAX]] from [[Boston Logan International Airport]] and [[Washington Dulles International Airport]] respectively.{{cite book|editor=Paul Joseph|title=The SAGE Encyclopedia of War: Social Science Perspectives|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=idw0DQAAQBAJ&pg=PA1533|year=2016|publisher=SAGE Publications|isbn=978-1-4833-5988-5|page=1533}} Other accidents include the [[American Airlines Flight 383 (2016)|Flight 383]] engine failure and fire in 2016. There were two training flight accidents in which the crew were killed and six that resulted in no fatalities.
